Schwab (6.6%)}} | subsid = {{Unbulleted list| Charles Schwab Bank| Charles Schwab Investment Management, Inc.| Charles Schwab Futures, Inc.| Charles Schwab Premier Bank| OptionsXpress| Schwab Performance Technologies| Charles Schwab Foundation| Charles Schwab Trust Bank| Schwab Holdings, Inc.| [[Scottrade]]| [[TD Ameritrade Network|TD Ameritrade Media Productions]]|[[TD Ameritrade]]}} | website = {{ubl|{{URL|https://www.aboutschwab.com}}|{{URL|https://www.schwab.com}}}} | footnotes = Charles Schwab Institutional Reporting: 2021{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/ix?doc=/Archives/edgar/data/316709/000031670922000009/schw-20211231.htm | title=US SEC: Form 10-K The Charles Schwab Corporation | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] | date=24 February 2022}}{{Cite web | url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/charles-schwab/ | title=Charles Schwab | publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]}}{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/316709/000119312522093320/d246025ddef14a.htm#rom246025_38 |title=Proxy statement |date=1 April 2022 |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}} }} '''The Charles Schwab Corporation''' is an American multinational [[Financial institution|financial services company]]. It offers [[bank]]ing, [[commercial bank]]ing, investing and related services including consulting, and [[wealth management]] advisory services to both retail and institutional clients. It has over 360 [[Branch (banking)|branch]]es, primarily in financial centers in the United States and the United Kingdom. It is the [[List of largest banks in the United States|7th largest banking institution]] in the United States with over US$8.5 trillion in client assets.{{cite web |title=Charles Schwab Corporation Form 10-Q - Q3 2020 |url=https://content.schwab.com/web/retail/public/about-schwab/SEC_Form10Q_09302020.pdf}} It had 29.0 million active brokerage accounts, 2.1 million corporate retirement plan participants, 1.5 million banking accounts, and $8.5 trillion in client assets as of February 7, 2022.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20201210006119/en/Schwab-Declares-Preferred-Stock-Dividend | title=Schwab Declares Preferred Stock Dividend | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=December 10, 2020}} It was founded in [[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]], and is headquartered in [[Westlake, Texas]]. Founded as '''Charles Schwab & Co.''' in 1971 by its namesake [[Charles R. Schwab]], the company capitalized on the financial [[Deregulation#United States|deregulation of the 1970s]] to pioneer [[Discounts and allowances|discount sales]] of equity securities. After a flagship opening in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], the bank expanded into [[Seattle]] before the [[Economy of the United States#History|1980s economic expansion]] financed the bank's investments in technology, automation, and digital record keeping. The first to offer round-clock order entry and quotation, it was purchased by [[Bank of America]] in 1983 for $55 million. Three years later, the profitability of the bank's no-charge [[mutual fund]]s prompted the founder to buy his company back for $280 million.{{cite news |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1987-04-01-fi-818-story.html |title=Schwab Completes Buyout of Brokerage From B of A |date=April 1, 1987 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190429123803/https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1987-04-01-fi-818-story.html |archive-date=April 29, 2019 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |author=John M. Broder}} ==History== [[File:Charles_Schwab_on_Nassau_Street.jpg|thumb|A Charles Schwab location in [[Princeton, New Jersey]]]] In 1963, [[Charles R. Schwab]] and two other partners launched ''Investment Indicator'', an investment newsletter.{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/personalfinance/2013/04/11/schwab-icon-of-the-small-investor/2070573/ | title=Icons: Schwab still roots for the small investor | first=John | last=Waggoner | newspaper=[[USA Today]] | date=April 11, 2013 }} At its height, the newsletter had 3,000 subscribers, each paying $84 a year to subscribe. In April 1971, the firm was incorporated in California as First Commander Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Commander Industries, Inc., for traditional brokerage services and to publish the Schwab investment newsletter. In November of that year, Schwab and four others purchased all the stock from Commander Industries, Inc., and in 1972, Schwab bought all the stock from what was once Commander Industries. In 1973, the company name changed to Charles Schwab & Co., Inc.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Og1VaPhkwwC | title=Charles Schwab: How One Company Beat Wall Street and Reinvented the Brokerage Industry | first=John | last=Kador | publisher=John Wiley & Sons | year= 2002| isbn=978-0471434313}}{{page needed|date=May 2020}} In 1975, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] allowed for negotiated commission rates and Schwab set up a [[stock brokerage]]. In September 1975, Schwab opened its first branch in Sacramento, CA, and started offering discount brokerage services. In 1977, Schwab began offering seminars to clients, and by 1978, Schwab had 45,000 client accounts total, doubling to 84,000 in 1979. In 1979, Schwab risked $500,000 on a back-office settlement system called BETA (which was short for Brokerage Execution and Transaction Analysis), enabling Schwab to become the first discount broker to bring automation in house. In 1980, Schwab established the industry's first 24-hour quotation service, and the total of client accounts grew to 147,000. In 1981, Schwab became a member of the [[NYSE]], and the total of client accounts grew to 222,000. In 1982, Schwab became the first to offer 24/7 order entry and quote service, its first international office was opened in Hong Kong, and the number of client accounts totaled 374,000. In 1983, [[Stephen McLin]] purchased the company for [[Bank of America]] for $55 million. In 1984, the company launched 140 no-load [[mutual fund]]s. In 1987, management, including Charles R. Schwab, bought the company from Bank of America for $280 million.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/03/business/bank-america-is-selling-schwab-unit-to-founder.html |title = Bank America Is Selling Schwab Unit to Founder |first=Lawrence M. | last=Fisher |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 3, 1987 |url-access=subscription }} In 1991, the company acquired Mayer & Schweitzer, a market making firm, allowing Schwab to execute its customers' orders without sending them to an exchange.{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/business/company-news-charles-schwab-in-an-acquisition.html | title =Company News; Charles Schwab In an Acquisition |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=June 6, 1991 }} In 1997, it was fined $200,000 for failing to arrange the best trades for its customers.{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/22/business/schwab-unit-agrees-to-pay-200000-fine.html |title=Schwab Unit Agrees to Pay $200,000 Fine | agency=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date=October 22, 1997 | url-access=subscription}} The unit was renamed Schwab Capital Markets in 2000.{{cite press release |url = https://www.td.com/document/PDF/investor/2001/2001-01-31-TDW%20Aitken%20Campbell%20JV%20with%20Schwab.pdf |title = Schwab and TD Waterhouse Join Forces to Build New UK Market Making Firm | publisher=[[Toronto-Dominion Bank]] | date=January 31, 2001}} In 1993, the company opened an office in [[London]]. In 1995, the company acquired The Hampton Company, founded by Walter W. Bettinger, who became CEO of Schwab in 2008.{{cite news | url=https://www.pionline.com/article/19951109/ONLINE/511090703/charles-schwab-acquired-the-hampton-co-a-defined-benefit-and-defined | title=Charles Schwab acquired The Hampton Co., a defined benefit and defined| publisher=Pensions & Investments Online | date=November 9, 1995}} In 1996, Web trading goes live. Customers can trade listed and OTC stocks, or check balances and the status of orders on the schwab.com website.{{cite news | url=https://www.aboutschwab.com/history | title=Company history | publisher=Charles Schwab Corporation}} In 1998, dissatisfied by the in-house results, the company hired interactive firm Razorfish to redesign the website. Years later the website would be entered in the Cooper-Hewitt Museum's inaugural National Design Triennial.{{cite news | url=https://www.aiga.org/the-artless-website-schwab-com | title=The Artless Website: schwab.com| publisher=American Institute of Graphic Arts | date=January 25, 2006}} In 2000, Schwab purchased [[U.S. Trust]] for $2.73 billion.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/14/business/schwab-to-pay-2.73-billion-for-us-trust.html | title=Schwab to Pay $2.73 Billion For U.S. Trust | first=Patrick | last=McGeehan | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 14, 2000 | url-access=subscription }} In 2001, less than a year after the acquisition of U.S. Trust, the U.S. Trust subsidiary was fined $10 million in a bank secrecy law case. It was ordered to pay $5 million to the New York State Banking Department and $5 million to the Federal Reserve Board.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/14/business/us-trust-is-fined-10-million-in-bank-secrecy-law-case.html | title=U.S. Trust Is Fined $10 Million in Bank Secrecy-Law Case | first=Michael | last=Brick | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 14, 2001 | url-access=subscription}} On November 20, 2006, Schwab announced an agreement to sell U.S. Trust to [[Bank of America]] for $3.3 billion in cash.{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/2006/11/20/bank-of-america-markets-equity-cx_jl_1120markets12.html| title=Bank of America To Buy U.S. Trust | first=Josh | last=Lipton | work=[[Forbes]] | date=November 20, 2006}} The deal closed in the second quarter of 2007. In January 2004, Schwab acquired [[SoundView Technology Group]] for $345 million to add [[equity research]] capabilities.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050922005566/en/Schwab-Completes-Acquisition-SoundView-Technology-Group | title=Schwab Completes Acquisition of SoundView Technology Group | publisher=Charles Schwab Corporation | via=[[Business Wire]] | date=January 16, 2004}}{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/20/business/company-news-schwab-to-buy-soundview-for-321-million.html | title=Schwab To Buy Soundview For $321 Million | agency=[[Bloomberg News]] | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=November 20, 2003 | url-access=subscription}} David S. Pottruck, who had spent the majority of his 20 years at the brokerage as Charles R. Schwab's right-hand man, shared the CEO title with the company's founder from 1998 to 2003. In May 2003, Mr. Schwab stepped down, and gave Pottruck sole control as CEO. On July 24, 2004, the company's board fired Pottruck, replacing him with its founder and namesake. News of Pottruck's removal came as the firm had announced that overall profit had dropped 10%, to $113 million, for the second quarter, driven largely by a 26% decline in revenue from customer stock trading. After coming back into control, Mr. Schwab conceded that the company had "lost touch with our heritage", and quickly refocused the business on providing financial advice to individual investors. He also rolled back Pottruck's fee hikes. The company rebounded, and earnings began to turn around in 2005, as did the stock. The share price was up as high as 151% since Pottruck's removal, ten times since the return of Charles Schwab.{{cite news| title=Charles Schwab steps down as CEO of his brokerage | url=https://latimesblogs.latimes.com/money_co/2008/07/charles-r-schwa.html| work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=July 22, 2008}} The company's net transfer assets, or assets that come from other firms, quadrupled from 2004 to 2008. Schwab's YieldPlus fund drew controversy during the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|2007 financial crisis]] because of its -31.7% return.{{cite web|url=https://www.slcg.com/pdf/workingpapers/Schwab%20YieldPlus.pdf|title=Charles Schwab YieldPlus Risk|last1=Deng |first1=Geng|last2=McCann|first2=Craig|year=2010|publisher=Securities Litigation & Consulting Group |last3=O'Neal|first3=Edward}} Investors in the Schwab YieldPlus Fund, including Charles Schwab himself, lost $1.1 billion.{{cite news|last=Norris |first=Floyd|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/14/business/14norris.html|title=At Schwab, Unkept Promise To Investors| date=January 14, 2011 | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |author-link=Floyd Norris| url-access=subscription}} Schwab closed the YieldPlus funds in 2011.{{cite news|last=Pender |first=Kathleen| url=https://blog.sfgate.com/pender/2011/06/24/schwab-shuttering-beleaguered-yieldplus-funds/| title=Schwab shuttering beleaguered YieldPlus funds|date=June 24, 2011 |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}} In April 2007, the company acquired The 401(k) Company.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070920006146/en/Schwab-Completes-Acquisition-401-Company | title=Schwab Completes Acquisition of The 401(k) Company | publisher=Charles Schwab Corp | via=[[Business Wire]] | date=April 2, 2007}} On July 22, 2008, Walter W. Bettinger, the previous [[chief operating officer]], was named chief executive, succeeding the company's namesake. Charles R. Schwab remained [[executive chairman]] of the company and said in a statement that he would "continue to serve as a very active chairman". In 2011, the company acquired OptionsXpress.{{cite press release| url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110831007072/en/Schwab-Completes-Acquisition-optionsXpress | title=Schwab Completes Acquisition of optionsXpress | publisher=Charles Schwab Corp | via=[[Business Wire]] | date=August 31, 2011}} The company also acquired Compliance11, Inc., a provider of compliance software.{{cite press release| url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20111116005867/en/Schwab-Completes-Acquisition-Compliance11| title=Schwab Completes Acquisition of Compliance11, Inc.| publisher=Charles Schwab Corp| via=Business Wire| date=November 16, 2011}} In 2012, it acquired ThomasPartners, an [[asset management]] firm.{{cite press release| url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20121015005686/en/Schwab-Announces-Agreement-Acquire-Thomas-Partners | title=Schwab Announces Agreement to Acquire Thomas Partners | publisher=Charles Schwab Corp | via=[[Business Wire]] | date=October 15, 2012}} On July 1, 2020, the company acquired Wasmer, Schroeder & Company, an independent investment manager of fixed income in separately managed accounts with $10.7 billion in assets under management.{{Cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20200701005204/en/Schwab-Completes-Acquisition-of-Wasmer-Schroeder-Company-LLC | title=Schwab Completes Acquisition of Wasmer, Schroeder & Company, LLC |date=July 1, 2020 }} On May 26, 2020, the company acquired [[USAA]]'s investment management accounts for $1.8 billion in cash.{{cite news | last=Santana | first=Steven | title=Schwab completes purchase of USAA Investment Management | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanantonio/news/2020/05/26/charles-schwab-completes-purchase-of-usaa-invest.html | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=May 26, 2020}}{{Cite news | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/26/charles-schwab-to-buy-usaa-assets-in-1point8-billion-deal.html | title=Charles Schwab to buy USAA assets in $1.8 billion deal | last=Cullen | first=Terri | website=[[CNBC]] |date=July 26, 2019}} In June 2020, the company began allowing investors to purchase fractional shares.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20200602005704/en/Schwab-Announces-Availability-of-Schwab-Stock-Slices%E2%84%A2 | title=Schwab Announces Availability of Schwab Stock Slices™ | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=June 2, 2020}} On October 6, 2020, the company completed the acquisition of [[TD Ameritrade]].{{Cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20201006005590/en/Schwab-Completes-Acquisition-of-TD-Ameritrade | title=Schwab Completes Acquisition of TD Ameritrade | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=October 6, 2020}}{{cite news | url=https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/charles-schwab-completes-acquisition-of-td-ameritrade-60619300 | title=Charles Schwab completes acquisition of TD Ameritrade | first=John | last=Baguios | work=[[S&P Global]] | date=October 6, 2020}}{{cite news | url=https://nebraska.tv/news/local/charles-schwab-completes-its-26b-purchase-of-td-ameritrade | title=Charles Schwab completes its $26B purchase of TD Ameritrade | agency=[[Associated Press]] | date=October 6, 2020}} Effective on January 1, 2021, the company moved its headquarters from San Francisco, California to [[Westlake, Texas]].{{Cite news | url=https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/charles-schwab-to-officially-move-headquarters-to-denton-county-on-jan-1/2514658/ | title=Charles Schwab to Officially Move Headquarters to Denton County on Jan. 1 | first=Hannah | last=Jones | work=[[KXAS-TV]] | date=December 28, 2020}} ==Marketing== In 2004, Charles Schwab chose [[Havas Worldwide]] (then called Euro RSCG) as its full-service [[advertising agency]]. The company launched a series of television ads featuring the slogan ''Talk to Chuck'' by Euro RSCG and directed/animated by [[Bob Sabiston]]'s [[Rotoshop|Flat Black Films]] in 2005. "Talk to Chuck" campaign appeared in print media, online, billboards, and branch offices.{{cite news | url=https://slate.com/business/2005/12/animation-in-ads-for-charles-schwab.html | last=Stevenson | first=Seth | title=Money Toons: The distinctive animated ads from Charles Schwab | publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | date=December 5, 2005}} A blog post in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' described the ads as effective because they included a single memorable phrase.{{cite news | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/experts/2014/08/06/why-talk-to-chuck-was-a-great-ad/ | title=Why 'Talk to Chuck' Was a Great Ad | last=Higgins | first=Michelle Perry | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=August 6, 2014 | url-access=subscription}} In February 2013, Schwab hired [[Crispin Porter + Bogusky]] (CP+B) as its lead creative agency with Havas Worldwide remaining to create ads for ActiveTrader and optionsXpress.{{cite news | url=https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/charles-schwab-completes-creative-search-147124/ | title=Charles Schwab Completes Creative Search: Crispin outstrips Fallon for lead role | last=Beltrone | first=Gabriel | work=[[AdWeek]] | date=February 7, 2013}} The company launched an advertising campaign by CP+B with the slogan ''Own Your Tomorrow'' that same year.{{cite press release| url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20130612005401/en/Charles-Schwab-Launches-New-Campaign-Celebrating-Spirit | title=Charles Schwab Launches New Campaign Celebrating the Spirit of Engagement | publisher=Charles Schwab Corp | via=[[Business Wire]] | date=June 12, 2013}} In March 2015, [[Adweek]] reported on marketing material created by CP+B for Schwab's Intelligent Portfolio service.{{cite news | url=https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/ad-day-meet-charles-schwabs-new-intelligent-nonhuman-pitchman-163418/ | title=Ad of the Day: Meet Charles Schwab's New Intelligent, Nonhuman Pitchman: CP+B builds embodiment of the company's robo-adviser | last=Gianatasio | first=David | work=[[AdWeek]] | date=March 12, 2015}} ==Schwab Charitable Fund== The Schwab Charitable Fund is a [[donor advised fund]] which allows clients the option to preserve the anonymity of their donations.{{cite web | url=https://www.schwabcharitable.org/charities | title=Schwab Charitable - Where to Give | publisher=Charles Schwab Corp}} Professionally managed accounts are only available through independent investment advisors working with Schwab Advisor Services, a business segment of The Charles Schwab Corporation. It accepts contributions of real estate, private equity or other non-cash assets via a charitable intermediary, with proceeds of the donation transferred to a donor-advised account upon liquidation. This intermediary considers donations on a case-by-case basis, with a typical requirement that assets be valued at $250,000 or more.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170710005264/en/Schwab-Charitable-Facilitates-1.5-Billion-Grants-Fiscal | title=Schwab Charitable Facilitates More Than $1.5 Billion in Grants in Fiscal Year 2017 | publisher=Charles Schwab Corp | via=[[Business Wire]] | date=July 10, 2017}} == SEC charges == In June 2022, the U.S. Security and Exchange Commission ordered Charles Schwab Corp to pay $187 million to settle its charges for failing to disclose fund allocations and misleading its [[robo-advisor]] clients. It was determined that between March 2015 to November 2018, Charles Schwab misled customers and prospective investors by allowing them to believe that its robo-advisor service had no hidden fees, and it did not inform the clients about the cash drag on their investments. The SEC stated that the company has made money from cash allocations in the robo-advisor portfolios by sweeping cash to its affiliated bank, loaning it out, and keeping the difference between the interest it earned on the loans and what it paid in interest on the robo-advisor clients.{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Katanga |date=June 13, 2022 |title=Charles Schwab subsidiaries to pay $187 mln to settle SEC charges |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/charles-schwab-subsidiaries-pay-187-mln-settle-sec-charges-2022-06-13/ |access-date=June 13, 2022}} ==See also== * [[List of largest banks in the United States]] * [[Deregulation#United States|Deregulation in the United States]] * [[Financial District, San Francisco]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * Cronin, Mary J.
